Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "add domain avatars.githubusercontent.com" (#9425) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[2FA] Update link msa/aad account page with legacy password account information." (#9408) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Changes
* Updated wording of the "Link Microsoft Account" page to include Legacy Account information.
* Legacy account page: This page will show when users have password account and are not part of the exception list.
* Link Microsoft account page: After a user with a legacy account issue sends a SR to us, we will verify the request and ownership. Once we approve it using our processes, the user will see this page and will be able to link their MSA if they know their password, otherwise they will be able to use the **Forgot your password?** link.

### Screenshot
#### Legacy account page
![Legacy Account](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/223597221-14a360b6-7ddc-48d3-97ac-7b8398fe6788.png)

#### Link MSA account page
![Linking account](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17834924/223597400-5abed200-6841-4bfb-9ee2-9c3fa30e1a78.png)

Addresses: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4617

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Status page should show the time zone of a timestamp." (#9428) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

Status page shows the timeline, but it is not clear about the time zone. It is better that a timestamp is marked with the time zone.

### Repro Steps

1. On this URL: https://status.nuget.org/
2. The time zone used in history is unclear.

### Expected Behavior

Status page lists the time zone of a timestamp.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41028779/224125738-6ee7add3-bedb-4642-856d-502dca48bc72.png)

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Revoke button besides delete button for api keys" (#9426) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

Hi.
I would be nice if there's `Revoke` button next to `Delete` so I don't have to delete the key after finish uploading the package.
That way I keep packaging globing pattern for next time. If I delete it, then I have to use my memory muscle to figure out correct pattern each time.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8766776/223483195-2d359990-dfe7-4873-bb43-09df3f654f62.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]Tooltip for "Package has Vulnerabilities" icon in version list renders offscreen when screen is narrow" (#9424) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1744522

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Pre-Requisites:
Press "Ctrl+Shift+I" to open developer tool.
Now in dock side click on "undock into separate window" so that developer tool will get open in separate window.
Zoom the browser of the screen to be tested to 200%.
Adjust the screen to 320px*256px.

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Version History" control and hit enter.
Apply reflow and observe whether "Version history" tooltip is not visible.

Actual Result:
On applying reflow, Version history tooltip in "Version" tab is not visible.

Expected Result:
On applying reflow, "Version history" tooltip in "Version" tab content should be completely visible.

Notes:
This tooltip is a custom (I believe Bootstrap) control and thus doesn't always follow browser expectation when rendering. As such, I believe it is rendering outside of the viewport when it renders on a narrow screen. Not 100% sure what the best option here is. One option is to have it render on the other side (left instead of right) when screen is narrow).

Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1745384

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen reader: JAWS, NVDA

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
"Packages returned for json" screen gets opened.
Check whether "More Information" link is descriptive or not.

Notes:
It should be sufficient for us to augment the More Information link to read "More Information about {PackageId}"

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]Screen reader starts over from beginning when applying filters." (#9422) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Url: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1749979

Environment Details:
App name: NuGet Service
#URL: [https://www.nuget.org](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https:%2f%2fwww.nuget.org%2f&data=05%7c01%7cv-nitipi%40microsoft.com%7c9a84307e7aa744a4b24208dafa5ca2fe%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c638097573052590837%7cUnknown%7cTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7c3000%7c%7c%7c&sdata=C8Eab3i6ixAmqsOjG4AxNT36z9WZQiXPbjDDkMcS5ME%3D&reserved=0)

OS and Browser Details:
Edition Windows 11 Enterprise
OS build 22621.1105.
Chrome version:  109.0.5414.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Screen reader: JAWS, NVDA

Repro Steps:
Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/
Navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
Navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
"Packages returned for json" screen gets opened.
Tab till filter present at left side of screen and apply any filter.
Observe that screen reader is announcing all the details from the beginning when we apply filter.

Actual Result:
Screen reader is announcing all the details from the beginning when we apply filter.

Expected Result:
Screen reader should not announce all the details from the beginning when we apply filter, it should only announce the status message that "812 packages returned for json"

Notes:
Unfortunately, I believe this is relatively nontrivial to fix on our side. From my understanding of this issue and the feature, this is caused by the fact that hitting applying appear to redo the search with filters enabled, causing a page refresh. When the page refreshes, context on keyboard nav etc is lost. In theory, it should be possible to pass context to the next page, but I am unsure that this the right fix long term.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: [Cross-platform Dotnet NuGet Sign] The message ‚ÄúPackage(s) signed successfully‚Äù lost after signing a package successfully with ‚Äúdotnet nuget sign‚Äù command" (#12123) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

.NET SDK Version: 7.0.100-rc.1.22431.12

### Worked before?

Worked well on .NET SDK 6.0.400

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps
1. Execute the [Dotnet nuget sign pre-step](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/teams/NuGet/_layouts/15/Doc.aspx?sourcedoc=%7b8a3c6685-1661-47f4-8807-b765ca62aea1%7d&action=edit&wd=target%28Package%20Signing%20Manual%20Test.one%7C0344a15b-01b1-4828-af4c-63fe53687f8a%2FDotnet%20nuget%20sign%20pre-step%7C708e56b6-a296-493e-a615-e0e18c55f96f%2F%29&wdorigin=703).
2. On Windows: Create a new test certificate: ` .\CreateTestCertificate.ps1 -AddAsTrustedRootAuthority -Password password -GenerateCerFile` (in the powershell "Developer Command Prompt"). 
3. On macOS: Copy the .cer file and the .pfx file from the above Windows machine to macOS machine. 
4. Where <CertificateFilePath> is the file path to the long-lived .cer or .pem file and <VersionedSdkDirectoryPath> is the directory path for the patched versioned .NET SDK directory (e.g.:  ./patchedSDK/sdk/7.0.100), add trust for the certificate: 
    On macOS: ` ./dotnet run --project ./Entropy/TrustTestCert/TrustTestCert.csproj --framework net7.0 -- add -c <CertificateFilePath> -vsd <VersionedSdkDirectoryPath> `
5. Use the patched "dotnet.exe" to sign a package. Where <PackageFilePath> is the test package path and <PfxFilePath> is the file path to the .pfx file, sign the test package: 
On macOS: ` ./patchedSDK ./dotnet nuget sign <PackageFilePath> --overwrite --certificate-path <PfxFilePath> --certificate-password password -v n`

#### Expected 
There is a message ‚ÄúPackage(s) signed successfully‚Äù after signing a package successfully.

#### Actual
The message ‚ÄúPackage(s) signed successfully‚Äù lost after signing a package successfully with ‚Äúdotnet nuget sign‚Äù command on MacBook as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/192995784-b870257b-643a-47e1-b7ee-d80863a67ba3.png)
#### Note
1. It is not a regression.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Difference in transitivity behavior between graph and non-graph restore" (#12482) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

17.6

### Worked before?

Probably not

### Impact

Other

### Repro Steps & Context

When a project in a graph doesn't support restore, it seems that transitivity effectively stops for non-graph restores, but is allowed for graph restores. The referenced project does not get added to `project.assets.json`, and thus its dependencies (transitive dependencies for the main project) are missed.

Attached repro: [graph-restore-repro.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/10962055/graph-restore-repro.zip)

Non-graph:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6445614/224835345-61600b21-76a2-4d64-84bd-4f58bfe36310.png)

Graph:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6445614/224835406-3fb48ac2-028f-4f96-a801-fa363b23f9ba.png)

I haven't been able to reason about this situation enough, but it seems like the non-graph restore is "wrong" here.

This is a simple graph of A -> B -> C. B here has restore disabled (in my real scenario, B and C here were vcxproj which do not support `PackageReference`). All 3 are restored (or not) properly, but in the non-graph case C is missing as a direct project reference to A due to the missing transitivity.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet list return code changed" (#12479) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

It appears the return codes for dotnet list have been changed to return 1 instead of 0 if there is a failure to list packages for an project in a solution. Previously this was not the case. The behavior change is breaking and has implications for build automation using dotnet list.

`src/MySln.sln package --vulnerable --include-transitive`

### Desired Behavior

Previously the command would return a 0 exit node. It would print something like The project DockerCompose\docker-compose.dcproj uses package.config for NuGet packages, while the command works only with package reference projects. for any projects it could not list. Recently it has been changed to return a non zero exit code which is breaking existing build automation logic.

### Additional Context

Originally Reported Here https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/30975

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NRE raised when trying to collect the existing packages during an Update operation" (#12472) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
1. Launch exp instance in debug mode
2. Set a breakpoint in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/f49ca00e27297fe7b4b82a2557d5b0caad907a06/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/Actions/UIActionEngine.cs#L327.
3. Open a project with at least package that needs update.
4. CLick update
5. See breakpoint get hit.

The effect of this is that the telemetry does not get sent, but the try/catch hides it.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VS crashed when installing a package with ‚Äúpackage config‚Äù format in C# Class Library (.NET Framework) project " (#12481) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.6.0.44

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

1. Create a C# Class Library (.NET Framework) project in VS.  

2. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select "Manage NuGet Packages‚Ä¶" menu item to open PM UI.  

3. Click settings button (top-right of right panel), check "Allow format selection on first package install" in "General" tab and click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button.  

4. Go to "Browse" tab, select a package (for example "Newtonsoft.Json") and click install button. 

5. Check "packages.config" in "Choose NuGet Package Manager Format", click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button and click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button in the "Preview Changes" window. 

#### Expected:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

The package should be installed successfully. 

#### Actual:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

VS crashed when installing a package with ‚Äúpackage config‚Äù format as below screenshot:‚ÄØ 
![MicrosoftTeams-image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/84695155/224635331-5e98a8aa-c3e0-48bb-9088-b978387a855a.png)
#### Notes: 

1.It doesn‚Äôt repro on VS Main\33508.150 + NuGet Client Dev\6.6.0.43 

2.It still reproes when using PMC install package. 

3.The repro rate is 100%. 

4.[Dump file](\\mlangfs1\public\v-cicili\Bug0313)


#### Verbose Logs:
```
Application: devenv.exe
Framework Version: v4.0.30319
Description: The process was terminated due to an unhandled exception.
Exception Info: System.AccessViolationException
   at VSLangProj157.References3.AddFiles(System.Array, System.Array ByRef)
   at NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio.VsMSBuildProjectSystem+<>c__DisplayClass76_0+<<AddReferenceAsync>b__0>d.MoveNext()
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(System.Threading.ExecutionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback, System.Object, Boolean)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(System.Threading.ExecutionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback, System.Object, Boolean)
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.AsyncMethodBuilderCore+MoveNextRunner.Run()
   at Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory+SingleExecuteProtector.TryExecute()
   at System.Windows.Threading.ExceptionWrapper.InternalRealCall(System.Delegate, System.Object, Int32)
   at System.Windows.Threading.ExceptionWrapper.TryCatchWhen(System.Object, System.Delegate, System.Object, Int32, System.Delegate)
   at System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherOperation.InvokeImpl()
   at System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherOperation.Invoke()
   at System.Windows.Threading.Dispatcher.ProcessQueue()
   at System.Windows.Threading.Dispatcher.WndProcHook(IntPtr, Int32, IntPtr, IntPtr, Boolean ByRef)
   at MS.Win32.HwndWrapper.WndProc(IntPtr, Int32, IntPtr, IntPtr, Boolean ByRef)
   at MS.Win32.HwndSubclass.DispatcherCallbackOperation(System.Object)
   at System.Windows.Threading.ExceptionWrapper.InternalRealCall(System.Delegate, System.Object, Int32)
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet/Dotnet restore leaves files behind in /tmp/NuGetScratch" (#12420) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

Latest version of .NET 6.0, .NET 7.0, and pre-release versions of .NET 8.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Build the following Dockerfile (ex. `docker build -t nuget-test -f .\Dockerfile .`)

```Dockerfile
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0 AS build
WORKDIR /source
RUN dotnet new console --no-restore
RUN dotnet restore --use-current-runtime
```

2. Run the created image: `docker run -it --rm nuget-test /bin/sh`
3. Inspect the `/tmp` directory to see the files left behind: `ls -lah /tmp/NuGetScratch/lock/`

Is this the expected result? These files left behind by NuGet are causing us permission issues when switching between root and non-root users in .NET docker containers. When a NuGet/dotnet restore is run as root, future NuGet commands ran by other users will fail. Is there a build server of sort that we accidentally terminate early in the container build?

Thanks.

### Verbose Logs
The following are the files left behind by NuGet in an example image that I built using the instructions above (some of the files are not due to NuGet restore like `.dotnet/shm`, while others like MSBuildTemproot are left behind by powershell installation):

```
drwxrwxrwx         0:0        0 B  ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tmp                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    drwxrwxrwx         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .dotnet                                                                                     drwxrwxrwx         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ shm                                                                                         drwx------         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 82d9253f-fac5-4dd9-863e-e95ad886c6f0                                                            drwx------         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ MSBuildTemproot                                                                                 drwxrwxrwx         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ NuGetScratch                                                                                    drwxrwxrwx         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ lock                                                                                        -rw-r--r--         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 02c1a6b1e6a189adc09794fab6791bf24a1841dd                                                -rw-r--r--         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 3b3fba4ea8f8b14f53e82a125bf28c4a69896605                                                -rw-r--r--         0:0        0 B  ‚îÇ   ‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 6f70e9594edbb2d12174c395fa5596b59259ef3e Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Icon is not shown for self hosted package" (#12425) at NuGet/Home
```
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

17.4.1+9a89d02ff 

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create your own package with an icon defined in the MyLib.csproj

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Project ToolsVersion="15.0" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
   <PropertyGroup>
      ...
      <PackageIcon>icon.png</PackageIcon>
      ...
   </PropertyGroup>

   <ItemGroup>
      ...
      <None Include="icon.png" Pack="true" Visible="false" PackagePath="" />
      ...
   </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

2. Restore all project dependencies using NuGet v6.4.0

`nuget restore .\MyLib.csproj -PackagesDirectory .\packages`

3. Use MSBuild for packaging
`MSBuild .\MyLib.csproj -t:Pack -p:Configuration=Release`

4. Publish the package to JFrog Artifactory using JFrog CLI

```
cd bin/Release
jf rt u "*.nupkg" myrepo-nuget/MyLib/
jf rt u "*.snupkg" myrepo-nuget/MyLib/
```

5. Icon does not show up neither in JFrog Artifactory nor in the package list in JetBrains Rider.

6. icon.png file is included into the .nupkg archive

7. The resulting MyLib.nuspec includes  <icon>icon.png</icon> in the metadata section, and is missing any files or contentFiles sections.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet list return code changed" (#12479) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

It appears the return codes for dotnet list have been changed to return 1 instead of 0 if there is a failure to list packages for an project in a solution. Previously this was not the case. The behavior change is breaking and has implications for build automation using dotnet list.

`src/MySln.sln package --vulnerable --include-transitive`

### Desired Behavior

Previously the command would return a 0 exit node. It would print something like The project DockerCompose\docker-compose.dcproj uses package.config for NuGet packages, while the command works only with package reference projects. for any projects it could not list. Recently it has been changed to return a non zero exit code which is breaking existing build automation logic.

### Additional Context

Originally Reported Here https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/30975

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Moving to the new .NET Foundation CLA service" (#68) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello everyone
The .NET Foundation is transitioning to a new CLA service and I'm posting here to let you know it's happening. Some background info:

The new CLA service is based off of https://github.com/microsoft/ContributorLicenseAgreement, except it uses the dotnet-policy-service app

- Current contributors do not need to sign the CLA again
- The CLA agreement itself is not changing
- As part of the install/configuration process, the following work items will be completed

1. Create a .github repo if it doesn't exist already
2. Install the dotnet-policy-service app
3. Create PRs for the platformcontext.xml and cla.yml files
4. Disable the existing CLA webhook
5. Push the PRs to enable the new CLA service

That's all there is to it. I'll update this issue once the work is complete

Thanks
Chris
.NET Foundation Operations team

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.org migration towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure" (#60) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In the coming weeks, nuget.org will be migrating towards a new multi-CDN infrastructure that will improve the experience of our users. This change allows our team flexibility to switch to a back-up provider in the case that one CDN is down, which will broaden coverage for our users.

Some changes are coming for older TLS cipher suites, which may result in connectivity issues. From our data we believe this will affect only a small percentage of requests. We will be monitoring all feedback channels during the migration to assess impact and adjust our roll-out timeline as needed.

Below, we provide resources to determine whether you will be affected by this change. This utilizes the [.NET CLI](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/) to install a package from our pre-production (INT) environment which tests connectivity:


```
mkdir cdn-test
cd cdn-test
dotnet new classlib
dotnet add package BaseTestPackage.NetStandard --source https://apiint.nugettest.org/v3/index.json
```

If you are experiencing connectivity issues while connecting to nuget.org or restoring packages from https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json, such as:

"The SSL connection could not be established"

Please ensure that TLS 1.2 and any of the following cipher suites have been enabled on your machine:

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256

If you have any questions, do reach out to us at‚ÄØsupport@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue:‚ÄØNuGet/Home#11058
